posts.name: Ethansaadia
posts.cooked:
I was successfully using my DGX Spark today until I loaded a 65GB model in LM Studio, and the system crashed. Now, when booting, I‚Äôm getting the GNOME error screen immediately after logging in:

Oh no! Something has gone wrong.
A problem has occurred and the system can‚Äôt recover. Please log out and try again.

I can switch to a TTY, and the keyboard works, but the mouse and desktop don‚Äôt load.

In journalctl, I‚Äôm seeing this repeatedly:

gnome-shell[5409]: Gio.DBusError: GDBus.Error:org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.Failed:
Set global engine failed: Operation was cancelled
@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/init.js:21:20

The error seems related to IBus / D-Bus initialization during GNOME startup. It happens both for my main user and for a test user account (the test one briefly showed the setup window, then crashed too).

So far I‚Äôve:

  • Confirmed the issue occurs on multiple users (so not just a single user config)

  • Verified keyboard input works (TTY and login), but mouse input does not

  • Checked logs showing the above GNOME Shell / D-Bus error

  • Created a recovery USB, but I can‚Äôt access UEFI ‚Äî holding the DEL key during boot doesn‚Äôt open the BIOS/UEFI menu on the Spark

I haven‚Äôt reinstalled any packages yet, since I wanted to confirm whether this is a known DGX OS 7 issue before modifying the system.

Questions:

  1. Is this a known problem with the current DGX OS 7 build on DGX Spark?

  2. Are there any recommended workarounds or updates (for GNOME, ibus, or xdg-desktop-portal)?

  3. Is there another key or method to enter the UEFI menu on Spark?

  4. Would reinstalling GNOME-related packages be safe without affecting CUDA or DGX management tools?

Thanks!

Hi spark903, sorry to hear you‚Äôre running into these issues. Just to confirm, have you installed all available system updates through the Spark Dashboard? We strongly recommend updating all software and firmware packages via the Dashboard before starting any workloads.

posts.name: Ethansaadia
posts.cooked: Thanks for the reply! The system updated automatically when it first powered on. I did not have a chance to check out the Spark Dashboard before the error, and now I can‚Äôt access the desktop interface. Are these same updates accessible via the CLI?
Spark903, are you using a Bluetooth keyboard?

posts.name: Ethansaadia
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm using a wireless Logitech keyboard/mouse via a USB receiver. It acts like a wired keyboard in that it works on any device plug and play without setup.

If possible, would you be able to collect the complete output of journalctl and attach it here, or send it to us? If you can also run sudo nvidia-bug-report.sh and collect the log file from that, that would also be helpful.

I‚Äôm surprised you‚Äôre not able to get into the UEFI menu, but just to rule out the wireless keyboard, do you have a wired keyboard you could try? Failing that, you should be able to get into the UEFI menu by running systemctl reboot --firmware-setup from inside DGX OS.

posts.name: Ethansaadia
posts.cooked: Thank you, I swapped it for a wired keyboard, which worked. I‚Äôm starting on reinstalling the OS. I also sent the log file via email

posts.name: Jontybowden
posts.cooked:
I recovered following a 2 step process:

Stage 1: Restoring the Basic Ubuntu Desktop

This stage purges and reinstalls the generic Ubuntu GNOME desktop packages to fix corruption and dependency conflicts, which resolved the core hang.

Step Command(s) Purpose
1. Purge Corrupted Desktop Packages sudo apt purge ubuntu-desktop gnome-shell gdm3 Forcibly removes all core desktop components, including the display manager (GDM) and GNOME shell, which were likely corrupted or in conflict.
2. Remove Residual Dependencies sudo apt autoremove Cleans up packages that are no longer needed after the purge, ensuring a clean slate.
3. Reinstall Generic Desktop sudo apt install --reinstall ubuntu-desktop gnome-shell gdm3 Downloads and installs fresh, non-corrupted copies of the standard Ubuntu desktop, fixing the GDM hang and restoring a working GUI.
4. Clean Up and Reboot sudo apt autoclean Removes downloaded package files to save disk space.
sudo reboot Restarts the system to load the fresh GDM and start the restored Ubuntu Desktop.

Stage 2: Restoring the Specialized NVIDIA DGX Desktop

This stage installs the NVIDIA DGX OS specific package that overlays the generic Ubuntu desktop with the customized theme, tools, and the essential DGX Dashboard.

Step Command(s) Purpose
1. Open Terminal (Once you are logged into the restored Ubuntu Desktop) You now have a working terminal environment.
2. Update Package Index sudo apt update Refreshes the package lists to ensure the system knows where to find the latest DGX-specific packages in the NVIDIA repositories.
3. Install DGX Desktop Package sudo apt install nvidia-system-station Crucial Step: This package installs the specific DGX configurations, desktop themes, and the DGX Dashboard interface needed to fully restore the DGX OS environment.
4. Final Reboot sudo reboot Restarts the system to activate the specialized DGX desktop environment and display manager configuration.

This is an excellent idea. Since the DGX Spark is a specialized system, documenting the exact recovery steps you took is the best way to ensure you can quickly fix this issue if it ever reoccurs.

The process you executed was a powerful graphical environment reset and specialized configuration re-application.

Here is the detailed, two-stage recovery procedure you successfully performed:

üìù DGX Spark Graphical Environment Recovery Procedure

This guide assumes the system boots to a command-line interface (TTY‚Äîusually accessible via Ctrl+Alt+F3 or F4) but the Graphical Display Manager (GDM) fails to load (i.e., you see a black screen).

Stage 1: Restoring the Basic Ubuntu Desktop

This stage purges and reinstalls the generic Ubuntu GNOME desktop packages to fix corruption and dependency conflicts, which resolved the core hang.

Step Command(s) Purpose
1. Purge Corrupted Desktop Packages sudo apt purge ubuntu-desktop gnome-shell gdm3 Forcibly removes all core desktop components, including the display manager (GDM) and GNOME shell, which were likely corrupted or in conflict.
2. Remove Residual Dependencies sudo apt autoremove Cleans up packages that are no longer needed after the purge, ensuring a clean slate.
3. Reinstall Generic Desktop sudo apt install --reinstall ubuntu-desktop gnome-shell gdm3 Downloads and installs fresh, non-corrupted copies of the standard Ubuntu desktop, fixing the GDM hang and restoring a working GUI.
4. Clean Up and Reboot sudo apt autoclean Removes downloaded package files to save disk space.
sudo reboot Restarts the system to load the fresh GDM and start the restored Ubuntu Desktop.

Stage 2: Restoring the Specialized NVIDIA DGX Desktop

This stage installs the NVIDIA DGX OS specific package that overlays the generic Ubuntu desktop with the customized theme, tools, and the essential DGX Dashboard.

Step Command(s) Purpose
1. Open Terminal (Once you are logged into the restored Ubuntu Desktop) You now have a working terminal environment.
2. Update Package Index sudo apt update Refreshes the package lists to ensure the system knows where to find the latest DGX-specific packages in the NVIDIA repositories.
3. Install DGX Desktop Package sudo apt install nvidia-system-station Crucial Step: This package installs the specific DGX configurations, desktop themes, and the DGX Dashboard interface needed to fully restore the DGX OS environment.
4. Final Reboot sudo reboot Restarts the system to activate the specialized DGX desktop environment and display manager configuration.

Summary of the Core Problem Solved

The combination of these steps corrected a package-level conflict that occurred deep within the display stack (likely involving gnome-shell, gdm, or a shared library). This conflict caused the desktop to silently freeze or crash before the login screen could display, even though the core NVIDIA driver itself was running (as confirmed by nvidia-smi output).
